By Alfie Sansom

James Cousins

Music journalists display a wonderful penchant for exaggeration - taking gross liberties with the truth and twisting the facts as we see fit, we crash through the boundaries of 'acceptable journalistic practice'.

The Futureheads

Does It Offend You, Yeah?

The Metros

Black Francis

By James Bithell

Touring Europe to promote last year's concept album Bluefinger and his new EP Svn Fngrs, Black Francis decided it might be nice to treat each city to a precore - like an encore but before the show, consisting of a few acoustic songs on the street near the venue.

Art Brut Live Review

By James Bithell

Art Brut may never go on to mega-stardom, but they are possibly one of the best live performers out there today. Certainly from their fan's reaction tonight, they're also here to stay.

Battle of the Bands - The Final

Magic P and the Innuendos wowed the crowds in a packed Vanbrugh college on Saturday night, partying their way to success in the Battle of the Bands final.

David Ford live

Having seen David Ford play live six times in the last couple of months people might say there was not much he could do to make me love him any more. They would be wrong.

I Was a Cub Scout - I Want You to Know...

Following the recent spate of indie/electronic crossovers, I Was a Cub Scout fuse hauntingly nostalgic synths with a stamping drumbeat as a foundation for soaring vocals to create a decidedly unique sound.

Matt Costa - California Waiting

Olivia Haughton talks influences, MySpace and skateboarding with hot new singer/songwriter Matt Costa exclusively for Nouse, and finds a talent who lives up to the hype currently surrounding him.

Lightspeed Champion - Falling Off the Lavender Bridge

Where Test Icicles were a whirlwind blast of skinny jeans, kinetic yelps and frazzled guitars, Lightspeed Champion is similarly representative of the open plains of Nebraska.

The joys of downloading?

Downloading is easier, far closer to my bed than the nearest branch of a major music retailer and, to risk stating the obvious, significantly cheaper.

In-Depth

The music industry has to come to terms with the idea that things will have to radically change in the future and this may even mean accepting that recorded music as a commercial product is doomed.

Idioteque

Following a highly successful electro night last term, the Idioteque team took things up another notch by inviting several members of London-based hip-hop group Foreign Beggars to headline a hip hop/dub night.

On The Up

Marling is anything but just another female singer-songwriter. Her beautiful alt-folk album, tinged with blues and country, is reminiscent of greats such as Joni Mitchell.

Johnny Flynn

There's a dynamism in the room as he deftly switches between instruments. His 24 years belie a natural wisdom and creativity far beyond his age.

Explosions in the Sky

A four-piece from Texas, Explosions In The Sky are one of the best-known proponents of the post-rock style.

Boy Kill Boy - Promises

The new single from Boy Kill Boy's second album Stars and the Sea marks a departure from previous hits 'Back Again', 'Suzie' and 'Civil Sin'.

Envy & Other Sins - Highness

The single itself is a punchy example of indie pop at it's finest. Envy & Other Sins have been compared to The Feeling, which seems slightly unfair as there is a lot more intelligence in their music.

Hercules & Love Affair (ft. Anthony Hegarty)

If you'd told me that the next big thing from DFA Records planned to utilize the "unique" vocals of Antony Hegarty, I would have imagined that it would have a produced a similar reaction to Robert Oppenheimer sharing his summer vacation plans with Ghandi.

The Bedlam in Goliath

If you like your music frantic, frenzied and undeniably proggy, then this could be your most anticipated album of the year.

Battle of the Bands - Heat 4

Thursday night's heat opened with a swing intro from Kayak Attack, which went fairly unnoticed by the audience until they launched into their 20 minute set of constant pounding rock fused with electro.

Battle of the Bands - Heat 3

Porcelain Flamingo opened the gig and marked the standard with their charismatic set that showcased their musical talents. They incorporated flute and funky soprano vocal solos into a comic set led by front man Mark Perkins.

Battle of the Bands - Heat 2

The second heat of Battle of the Bands 2008 saw Magic P and the Innuendos storm to victory in the second heat of Battle of the Bands, rounding off an excellent night of music with a top quality performance that got the crowd moving.

Battle of the Bands - Heat 1

Read our music team opinions of the opening night of Battle of the Bands 2008. Featuring Superfuzz, Low Flying Flags, The Spoon and The Hero Status. Low Flying Flags won on the night.

2007: The Year In Music

Radiohead changed the course of human history - Or so it was claimed in some quarters. Their novel album release method certainly started a debate but it remains to be seen whether it was anything more than a gimmick.

CSS: Manchester Academy

<strong>Location:</strong> Manchester Academy <strong>Rating:</strong> * * * CSS are in danger of becoming overexposed. It's no longer cool to say you saw them on the January 07 NME tour.

Interview

The Brascoes were born early last year when old friends Dan Jones and Nove drunkenly decided to form a band.

Patrick Wolf: Empire, Shepards Bush

<strong>Location:</strong>Empire, Shepards Bush <strong>Rating:</strong> * * * * The relationship between Patrick Wolf's music and his live performance is an interesting one. He has concocted a powerful stage persona.

Orange Goblin: Fibbers, York

<strong>Venue:</strong> Fibbers, York <strong>Rating:</strong> * * * * "This is the first time that we've been to York" proclaimed Orange Goblin lead singer Ben Ward "it's taken us ten years to get here." Well, better late than never.
